question: I'm adjusting okay. Apartment's okay. It gives me headaches. Yeah.
answer: Good. I'll talk to your physician about the headaches. Maybe he can change the prescription.

question: The job's okay.
answer: Do I take "okay" to mean you feel good about working there?

question: I said the job is okay.
answer: That's right, you did. pause) Have you made any friends there?

question: I'm not running for Mr. Popularity.
answer: You seem a little hostile today.

question: That was a joke.
answer: No need to call me doctor. I'm a therapist, not a psychiatrist.

question: It's all the same.
answer: Walter, I'd like you to try something for me.

question: What?
answer: I'd like you to keep a journal.

question: Diaries have sent too many guys to prison.
Ev-i-dence.
answer: Oh. It never crossed my mind.

question: Bad idea.
answer: I thought a journal would encourage you to reflect.

question: How's that?
answer: By reflection we can derive a deeper meaning from our experience in life. We gain greater understanding about ourselves that can lead to making better choices in our relationships, our careers, and our goals.

question: You read that in a book.
You still think fast.
answer: Don't need to think fast to handle beer.

question: ook some talking to convince your super I was a relative.
answer: I told her all my relatives are good-looking.

question: Jesus Christ, man, it's good to see you!
answer: Seems like the whole world's gotten younger.

question: You doing okay?
answer: Got a job at old Frank's place. His son runs it now.

question: Oh man, that kid takes himself real serious.
Booming. Lots of building going on. We can't keep up with all the work. In fact, I just hired a few new guys...
answer: I just recommended you. You still had to prove yourself.

question: Living across the street from a grade school. Jesus.
I was just thinking of... the noise.
What?
answer: Law says I can't come within one hundred feet of where children congregate. I figure the distance from my window to the school is one hundred and twenty. Make a bet?

question: No way, man, you'd rob me blind!
answer: You find me a decent place for under three hundred a month in this town, and I'll happily move out of this crap neighborhood.

question: I should go. Your sister worries, and when she worries she yells.
I don't know. She won't talk about it.
answer: You're the only one in the family who still talks to me.

question: I remember when they all referred to me as "the little spic poor Annette married." Except her brother. You treated me with respect. pause) Look, you paid your dues. Your slate is clean now.
She'll be twelve next week. We're throwing a big party on Saturday. Wish I could ask you to come...
answer: Only if it's no closer than a hundred feet. One hundred and ten, one hundred and eleven, one hundred and twelve...

question: GOD DAMN IT! PEDRO! WHAT THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE DOING! HOW
It's fucking freezing out here. There's something wrong with this picture.
Very weird.
answer: No weirder than a sharp, young, good-looking woman working in a lumberyard.

question: Guess I'm not like most women.
You don't hang out with the other guys.
They're all assholes. You never spoke to me before.
answer: I thought you were a dyke.

question: Your windows face south. Northern light is the purest. But southern light is very good.
My place faces a truck street. I've got cracks in every window from the shaking.
I go backpacking a lot. Lose myself in the wilderness for a week or two.
So... what's your dark secret?
answer: Why do you want to know?

question: Don't you think I should know before we have sex?
Are you going to tell me your deep dark secret before we have sex?
I didn't say I didn't enjoy it.
answer: Of course. Sorry. I'm such a fucking asshole.

question: No you're not.
answer: Don't tell me I'm not a fucking asshole when I know I'm a fucking asshole!

question: What's the Wproblem?
answer: You think I have a problem?

question: I thought I'd stay the night.
Well, Walter, this is going to sound off-the-wall, but I like to sleep with a man after we fuck.
Is that all?
answer: When I do sleep, I sweat a lot. Usually I get nightmares and wake up screaming.

question: I sleep like a dead horse. Anything else?
answer: I watch the kids arrive at school.

question: I'm still thinking about it.
answer: I wish you'd give it a try.

question: It's okay.
answer: But you don't like coming here. Be honest, Walter.

question: Honest? No.
answer: Good. That's an honest answer. And why don't you like coming here?

question: Honest? Your cheery personality makes my skin itch.
answer: Is it just my cheery personality that makes your skin itch?

question: Forget it.
answer: Maybe it's the way I look. Or the sound of my name.

question: Rosen? I don't have a problem with that.
answer: Because if you did, I know a therapist named Ryan. I also know a therapist named Chung.

question: The new man. I'd keep away from him, if I were you.
You don't want to know, but he's damaged goods -- real damaged goods, if you know what I mean.
answer: Yeah, Mary-Kay, I think I do. Thanks a bunch for the advice.

question: Just trying to be helpful.
answer: Well, Mary, you're about as helpful as a broken sewer pipe. You do know what runs out of a sewer pipe, don't you?

question: What happened to you?
answer: Why do you want to know?

question: Because I like you.
answer: What's the worst thing you ever did?

question: You're not joking.
answer: Twelve years in prison is no joke.

question: How many girls did you molest?
What did you do to them?
How young?
answer: Between ten and twelve. Once a nine- year-old told me she was eleven. Once a fourteen-year-old told me she was twelve. I always asked how old they were.

question: So it was mostly fondling? Shit like that?
Twelve years in prison?
answer: The judge had a thing about sex offenders. Later I heard his daughter had been raped. If I hadn't had a good lawyer, it would have been twenty-five to thirty.

question: I told you I'm not easily shocked.
answer: You should be shocked. Or do you get off on this shit?

question: Walter.
answer: Get the fuck out of here!

question: You don't molest little girls anymore, do you?
It's made from cherry. That's a hard wood.
Notice the grain. See how deep and rich the red runs?
It's my own design. You won't find another table like it in the world.
Then why the fuck are you giving it back to me?!
he was going to throw it out, wasn't she? Just toss it like a scrap of wood.
Then what? What?!
answer: he's got all this new furniture now. She said it didn't fit anymore, so I kept it in the attic. I thought you might like it.

question: I made that table for you and Annette, for your wedding. I put a lot of love into it.
answer: I know, man. I love this table too. But I also love my wife.

question: Mariners are pounding the shit out of the Tigers.
Fucking Tigers. They got no pitching except for a bunch of green kids straight out of Double A or Southern Cal. How was the party?
The birthday party.
answer: Oh, Anna's. It was great, man. Anna was so pretty. getting excited) She looked like a princess, like one of those girls in a fairy tale, you know, like Snow White.

question: I don't want to see any goddamn pictures.
answer: They're just photos I took of the party.

question: Carlos. I want to see my sister and Anna in person. Okay?
She was born after they put me away. How can I have feelings?
answer: Then why are you talking about this?

question: Have to talk about something.
answer: What are you afraid will happen?

question: I'm not afraid. I'm just saying that Carlos has a thing for his daughter, and if he isn't careful he's going to suffer.
answer: Have you talked to Carlos about your concerns?

question: If I'm not, then what the hell am I doing here?
answer: Why do you think you're here?

question: You know why. It's part of the parole deal.
answer: Is that what you are angry about?

question: Talking to you is like riding on a merry-go-round.
answer: That is a marvelous image, Walter. Because by going in circles we find the things we missed the first time around.

question: How long is this going to take?
answer: We have a few more minutes.

question: I mean, when will I be normal.
answer: We have a lot of work to do.

question: Then how do you know if your patients are getting better?
How do they know?
answer: What is your idea of being normal?

question: What is your idea of being a Jew?
answer: Whatever my ideas are of being a Jew is not going to help you. looks at the clock) Why don't we continue this on Thursday.

question: I want to be normal!
answer: Then go see a therapist who will tell you you're normal!

question: You don't know!
answer: I know you're frustrated, Walter, but --

question: So what should I do? Call the cops? he laughs) Yeah, that's pretty funny.
answer: Hi, Walter. How are you doing?

question: Fine thanks.
answer: You know, it's really a beautiful day out there, and I was thinking -

question: Excuse me. Got another load coming in.
answer: Don't die on me, you little shit. You want to go for a ride? What was prison like? Yes! I want to know.

question: Prison is... time.
answer: You mean the time you're locked away?

question: No. Prison is time. That's it. You think time, you feel time, you hear time. Your heart doesn't beat to live, it just beats... time.
Don't be sorry for me. I did those things. No one else did. I'm dealing with that.
answer: My father took me fishing here when I was a kid. He could name every fish in the lake. And for every fish he named, he had a fishing story. I hated fishing, but I loved his stories.

question: Sounds like a special guy.
answer: My father was an alcoholic who drank himself right into the grave.

question: I was always the one seduced.
No. That's what I used to tell myself. V
answer: And what do you tell yourself now?

question: Okay. Then take me home.
answer: I want you to change my mind!

question: I had this plan once... or maybe it was a dream. I was going to quit the building business... open my own shop. Make and design fine country furniture. I had saved enough money. I found the perfect place. Cheap five-year-lease. The loan was in the bag. My wife was a hundred percent behind it. Everything was set... Then I got in trouble. Do you know what the worst kind of trouble is? gently) You know, this is crazy.
Most people say the odds are against me.
The percentages --
answer: Well, most people are stupid. pause) You want to talk about odds? One day I'll tell you how I survived as the youngest in a family of three sons. You wanna talk about odds?

question: Why not tell me now?
answer: I got poked around... here and there.

question: No you don't.
answer: I love all of them. They're strong, gentle men with families of their own. And if you asked them about what they did to me, they'd call you a fucking liar and then beat the shit out of you.

question: You never asked them about it?
So I am. But I always like to ask.
I think you do.
answer: Why don't you just tell me?

question: Then you won't mind if I look around.
I could get a search warrant.
answer: If you could, you would have brought one today.

question: Unusual design for a contemporary piece.
Who said I wanted to buy it?
answer: If you tell me when this happened --

question: Move your fucking hands away from your pockets!
answer: You can't talk to me like --

question: Like a piece of shit? In my eyes, you are a piece of shit. Think anyone would miss you if I threw you out the window right now?
answer: Okay. I followed a girl. I don't know why I did it. She was pretty. Very pretty. No, I'm --

question: Okay. I followed a girl. I don't know why I did it. She was pretty. Very pretty. No, I'm --
answer: Did she know that you were following her?

question: I don't know.
answer: What did you think would happen?

question: I don't know.
answer: What did you want to happen?

question: Of course it is! That's why I'm telling you!
answer: I want you to calm down.

question: I want to talk about it now.
answer: We'll talk about it more on Thursday.

question: Now I know. It's when I can see a girl, be near a girl, even talk to a girl... and walk away. That's my idea of being normal. Maybe this isn't a good idea.
Maybe you should be.
answer: Well, Walter, I got an idea of my own.

question: It's a bad idea.
answer: I think it's a fucking good idea.

question: I don't even know how to live with myself.
Most people don't have my kind of problems.
answer: Guess that makes you pretty special.

question: She's gone. That was easy. hat's this?
I don't need a plant.
answer: Everyone needs a plant. This ivy is one tough baby. It's a cutting from one of mine.

question: I said I was sorry.
answer: I can't move my patients around to accommodate one person.

question: You mean my problem?
answer: If by "problem" you mean your desire for prepubescent girls, yes.

question: What?
answer: I'd like you to close your eyes.

question: I'm relaxed.
answer: Close your eyes and let your mind be blank.

question: Hey, Rosen, you going to hypnotize me?
answer: No, I am not going to --

question: Okay. Eyes closed, mind a blank. I'm all yours. Do it, Rosen.
answer: When I say the word "girl" what is the earliest image that you can remember?

question: Nothing. Can I open my eyes?
answer: No. When I say the word "pretty," when I say the word "pleasure," what is the earliest memory you see?

question: I don't see --
answer: In your mind, Walter. Take your time. Where is she? What is she doing? ow old --

question: In my bed, Rosen. Where do you think?
In my bed too.
answer: How old are you and your sister?

question: I'm maybe about six... which would make her four.
Just lying there. We're taking a nap.
Yes, a nap. Kids do that. You ever take a nap, Rosen?
answer: Did you and your sister often take naps together?

question: I want you back in your chair! Right now!
I don't like nobody behind my back!
answer: I'm sorry. I shouldn't have been there.

question: Nothing.
answer: Did you touch her? Did you take off her clothes? Did you take off your clothes?

question: Okay I'll tell you what I did -- just to shut you up! I smelled her hair.
That's all. I just liked smelling her hair.
I was six years old!
answer: I meant later... when you two took naps.

question: It was a small house.
answer: All right. A small house... with small rooms.

question: I smelled her hair. That's it. I just liked smelling her hair.
Tell Annette I'm busy in July.
You should see my appointment book. It got crazy.
Isn't it?
answer: The important thing is that you and Annette need to talk. She needs to see you, and you need to see her.

question: I'm not a monster.
answer: You're a good man, Walter. Okay, you did some wrong things, but inside you're a good, decent man.

question: Maybe I'm not a good man. Maybe inside I'm bad, and I'll always be bad.
You don't have to tell me this.
Carlos, I never raped a woman.
answer: I know. I'm just saying I understand.

question: Maybe because you're looking her in the face.
answer: I see a pretty woman, I look. That's the price of beauty, my friend. My god, you should see what Anna's friends wear.

question: Carlos, can I ask you something?
answer: Sure. Ask me. Ask me anything.

question: Did you ever... Do you have feelings for Anna?
I mean... feelings.
answer: Listen, man. I don't got your sick problem, and if you or anybody else ever comes near my daughter, I'll kill you.

question: Walter...
answer: Don't touch me... please. Good morning, fellow sports fans. The match is about to begin. Candy enters the arena looking sweet and trim. He checks out the scene but plays it cool. He's definitely holding back. Uh-oh, Candy's eyes have locked onto something. Oh yeah.

question: Do what?
answer: Sneak up behind me like that.

question: What's your fucking problem?
answer: Why's it always my fucking problem?

question: Do you want to talk about it?
There's a million birds here.
answer: In that birch tree is a nest. Up there.

question: There's little chicks! You want to see?
They're extremely aggressive birds. Plus, their habits are rather filthy.
answer: The mother sure has her hands full.

question: When I go bird-watching. It's why I like coming here.
You'd be surprised how many kinds of birds you'll see here. Last week I saw a purple martin. And the week before that, I saw a solitary vireo. That's rare.
answer: A solitary vireo. I like that one.

question: Not too far.
answer: Me? Nah. I'm more of a people watcher.

question: Were you watching me?
answer: Not at first. You would stare at the tops of the trees so intently. Any second I thought you would take off and fly.

question: I have to go.
answer: Do you come here often? It's good to listen to your daddy.

question: Maybe it's like Rosen said. Maybe I wanted nothing to happen. Fucking Rosen! This isn't helping.
What can I do for you, Sergeant Lucas?
What?
answer: Your ivy. Too much direct sunlight. These plants don't like a lot of sun. W

question: They grow outside, don't they?
answer: Sure they do. But outside they've got trees around them. The trees shade them from the sun. Of course, the plants enrich the soil around the trees. One of nature's symbiotic relationships.

question: You going to take me on a nature walk?
answer: Don't be witty. Yesterday you took the number twelve bus from work, but instead of getting off at your normal stop, for some reason you stayed on. Why did you stay on the bus, Walter?

question: Yes.
answer: Some of these guys... They walk right into a family's home as if they live there. Very fucking ballsy.

question: No.
answer: Neither do I. What's the one with the woodsman?

question: I don't know.
answer: Sure you do. He cuts open the wolf's stomach, and the girl steps out alive.

question: Little Red Riding Hood.
answer: That's it. Little Red Riding Hood jumps out of the wolf's guts with hardly a scratch. Ever see a seven-year-old girl sodomized almost in half?

question: The girl.
answer: I don't know why they keep letting scum like you return to the streets. It just means we've got to catch you all over again.

question: I have friends.
answer: A pretty girl like you should have a lot of friends.

question: I'm not pretty.
answer: Well... not in the common way.

question: What does that mean?
answer: It means uncommon beauty is commonly overlooked. Most people only notice birds with the brightest colors.

question: Yeah, like the bird.
answer: Can I ask how old you are?

question: I will be in three months. I can't wait. I hate being eleven. It has to be the stupidest age in the world.
How come?
answer: A long time ago, I was sent far away. When they let me come back, all my friends were gone.

question: It sounds like you were banished.
Birds are my friends. That sounds egotistical, but they are. Birds know I watch them, but they don't mind because they like being watched... if they know you won't hurt them.
Yes?
answer: Would you like to sit on my lap?

question: What?
answer: Would you like to sit on my lap?

question: I'm sure. Thank you all the same.
Do you want me to sit on your lap?
They sound like finches.
answer: They could be finches. I don't know. We should go before it gets dark.

question: My daddy lets me sit on his lap.
Yes.
answer: Do you like it when he asks you?

question: Ms. Kramer.
answer: Tell Ms. Kramer what your daddy does.

question: What will happen if I do?
answer: Someone will talk to your daddy. And then he'll stop doing those things... the things you don't like.

question: But will he... ?
answer: Your daddy will always love you.

question: How do you know?
answer: I know because... it's just something I know.

question: I don't want to hurt my daddy.
Do you still want me to sit on your lap?
Can't I stay a little longer?
What can I do for you, Sergeant Lucas?
Know what?
answer: I'll be asking the questions. Last night, you hear anything unusual? Screams? Shouts?

question: No.
answer: man was badly beaten across the street. You know anything about that?

question: I was asleep.
answer: I didn't say what time the assault occurred.

question: You said last night. I went to bed pretty early.
answer: The assault took place at approximately seven thirty.

question: I went to bed around seven.
You could. It'd be a waste of your time, though.
I suppose if you're looking for a male between the ages of thirty and fifty, medium height, medium weight, medium build. Probably not too many men fit that bill.
answer: Just give me a straight answer, Walter, cause the irony goes right over my head.

question: You're a cop. Figure it out.
It's a free country, isn't it?
Yes.
answer: Then I'd say you're a lucky fellow.

question: I count my blessings.
answer: Well, I guess I'll be seeing you.

question: Think you'll catch this guy?
answer: Oh, yeah. We'll catch him. Unfortunately, the victim can't talk. In addition to his other injuries, his jaw is broken.

question: `Fraid not.
answer: Stay out of trouble, Walter. Cause I'll be watching you.

question: Fucking liar.
answer: I heard they were filthy birds.

question: Not when they fly.
answer: I saw my sister. It was hard.
